body:
The reason it cancels the click event is so that you can drag elements that have click listeners without triggering their click event on mouseup. For example, in a force layout, you might have clickable nodes, but the click action is only triggered when the node is clicked on without dragging.

Could you describe the problem in Opera more explicitly? What behavior are you seeing?

That makes sense, thanks.

Opera doesn't trigger click events if the mouse has moved while down. Other browsers trigger, as long as its within the element. The next click after dragging is captured and stopped.

I'm not sure if this behavior is considered a bug or expected behavior by Opera. I've filed a bug report, but no response yet.
http://bl.ocks.org/4611759

issue.title: opera requires users to click twice after panning the map, in order to add a node

labels.name: bug-browser-specific
labels.description: A bug that only appears in certain browsers

repository.name: iD
repository.description: ðŸ†” The easy-to-use OpenStreetMap editor in JavaScript.

issue.body:
this is opera-specific as far as we know.

This appears only to happen after a pan.

/via @ToeBee

body:
Not sure if you want to include a special case for this, but a possible fix: https://github.com/ansis/d3/commit/3f115f301cb67963a0647a11bed47b6f1dc05bcd

This may or may not be a bug in Opera. It could be intentional. Either way [W3 spec](http://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Events/#event-type-click) allows behavior like Opera's:

> the click event **may** be dispatched if one or more of the event types mouseover, mousemove, and mouseout occur between the press and release of the pointing device button

Opera only triggers a click event if the mouse has moved <= 5px after mousedown.

There is another issue with blocking clicks. If an element is reinserted, a click doesn't get triggered in Chrome (probably all webkit browsers) even if mousedown and mouseup are on that element. A click does get triggered in Firefox.

http://bl.ocks.org/ansis/791a9dc6a4d92cae41a1

Predicting whether a click is coming is pretty complicated, so it might be better to not block it ever, and let the user implement their click function considering a click might be triggered after dragging.

I ran into this issue recently, with consistent [undesirable] behavior both in Firefox and Chrome.  After dragging an element with d3.behavior.drag, the next mouse click would always be consumed by the post-drag click suppression (even if the click was made to a completely different element).

I may be running into something similar to what @ansis describes above (i.e. we may be changing the DOM during the drag); I could try to put together a minimal demonstration case of the bug as it presents in our case.

I've implemented a kludgy yet perhaps more straightforward fix that I think should handle the case of browsers inconsistently firing a click event at dragend, unbinding the click-absorbing callback on a 0-ms timeout: appneta@69b907b8ec712d94943192eada0dab778371a4d5

I just realized that my patch and comment were for _drag_, not zoom.  Sorry for the confusion!  Both the zoom and drag click-absorption-at-end are similar and perhaps the same fix would apply in both cases.

body: Removing the click-canceling listener after a 0ms timeout seems like a reasonable (if slightly hacky) solution. There definitely shouldnâ€™t be any reason for that listener to exist more than an instant, anyway.

issue.title: d3.behavior.zoom on IE browser

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
Hi.
I have some problems when I use d3.behavior.zoom event with drag on Internet Explorer.
I have a svg with several elements. Each element has a xlink:href associated, and when I call the d3.behavior.zoom, I lose the possibility of executing the xlink:href. When I click on an element, nothing happens. 
If I set .on(â€œmousedown.zoomâ€, null), the links work fine, but obviously I lose the drag.
How can I fix this?
Regards,
Carlos.

body:
In my problem https://github.com/mbostock/d3/issues/1146 even if I don't drag the elements, the click to the xlink:href doesn't work. Doesn't matter how many times I click on an element, the click to the xlink:href doens't work on IE (on FF or Chrome everything works fine). I read the posts above but I couldn't fix this problem yet.
I tried a different solution too, that was setting .on(â€œmousedown.zoomâ€, null) and applying the drag behavior. With that I have no problems with the clicks but another problem arose https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/d3-js/SbYDOdIxlYk.
How can I fix one of these two options?
Thanks,
Carlos.

issue.title: Fix for #1005 - fix click suppression after dragend in cases where click doesn't fire.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
Fixes Issue #1005 for both behavior.zoom and behavior.drag

This fixes (which we're using at appneta to fix this issue in our app for both zoom and drag) cases when code intended to suppress superfluous click events on dragend causes a later click (anywhere on the page) to be absorbed.

Since the undesired click event should fire immediately after dragend, before returning to the JS event loop, the 0ms setTimeout where we clear the handler would only ever fire after the click event.  This should also take place fast enough that most human users would never make a subsequent click before the setTimeout fires.

This is a bit hacky as noted in https://github.com/mbostock/d3/issues/1005#issuecomment-15592805, but is probably less complicated than trying to discern cases/browsers/versions where the click does and does not fire.

issue.title: d3.behavior.zoom shouldnâ€™t d3_eventCancel touchstart.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
I imagine this is related to #1005 / #1175.

I had implemented panning using `d3.behavior.drag`, and switched to using `d3.behavior.zoom` and now all the elements with tap/click events are no longer responding to taps, but are happily responding to clicks.

Here's a minimal example: http://bl.ocks.org/fidothe/5378483

Obviously, to see the tap-eating you need to view it on a touchscreen device...

Does whatever was done in #1175 need tweaking, or is there a deeper issue?

body:
I've observed inconsistent behavior with v3.5.8 in Chrome, as have others in the comments at http://stackoverflow.com/a/19951105/877682.

I don't see this behavior with simple examples like http://jsfiddle.net/2EqA3/3, leading me to believe that the inconsistency has to do with our draggable nodes, which are complex, comprising multiple path and text elements

I've worked around the problem by changing d3: when dragRestore doesn't check if d3.event.target === target, this issue goes away for me. I haven't observed side effects caused by this, but I don't understand the code well enough to know what to test. https://github.com/mbostock/d3/commit/a8de36bd85cecafbc76f6e4c7e5d80b9b280b500

The issue you are seeing is indeed related to draggable nodes with multiple elements. See #312 and specifically @jasondaviesâ€™ comment:

> The problem is that the browser only fires a click event if mousedown and mouseup occur on the same element. So if you have a mousedown occurring on one element, and then mouseup on another, no click event is fired. This could happen in a number of ways e.g. if you clamped the dragged element and mouseup occurred outside the clamp region.
> 
> We had mistakenly assumed that a click event is always fired after mousedown + mouseup, so we always cancelled the next click event. In the original bug report, the OP found that he had to double-click on links after dragging a different element, because the next click was always being cancelled. We only want to cancel the click if it is actually going to be fired as a result of the mousedown + mouseup combination, which isn't always the case.

That said, it looks like we donâ€™t need this sanity-check since we added the 0ms timeout, which automatically expires click suppression if a click event doesnâ€™t immediately fire. In other words, since we only suppress an _immediate_ click event, we donâ€™t have to worry about false positives due to inconsistent browser behavior. (Before the 0ms-timeout, the click could be suppressed indefinitely!)

So, Iâ€™d be okay with removing target checks and relying on the timeout for click suppression.

issue.title: Suitably zealous click canceling.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body: This reverts #312, since we later implemented a more robust check in #1005 using a zero-delay timeout to expire click suppression.

body: Great, thanks for the context and fix!
